content:
The justices are about to consider a number of Donald Trump’s most wrap-span">controversial policies

IT HAS been a fairly quiet few months at the Supreme Court. Since early October, the justices have heard 32 wrap-span">oral arguments in mostly wrap-span">tame cases and have issued three decisions, all wrap-span">unanimous. After the wrap-span">partisan rancour of wrap-span">Brett Kavanaugh’s wrap-span">confirmation hearings, the justices—and perhaps especially Chief Justice John wrap-span">Roberts, who wrap-span">strives to keep the court above the political wrap-span">fray—have probably been wrap-span">relieved to keep a low wrap-span">profile.

But that may change as 2019 begins. The justices have already accepted three high-wrap-span">profile cases to be heard in the spring.  Dept. of Commerce v USDC,  up for wrap-span">oral argument on February 19th, wrap-span">embroils the justices in a wrap-span">procedural matter involving wrap-span">litigation over the Trump administration’s wrap-span">proposed citizenship question on the 2020 wrap-span">census; the outcome could shape elections and state funding through 2030.  American Legion v American wrap-span">Humanist Association, the court’s first major church-state case in half a decade, is a First wrap-span">Amendment challenge to a cross-shaped war wrap-span">memorial on public ground in wrap-span">Maryland that will be heard on February 27th. In March or April,  Kisor v Wilkie will give the justices a chance to draw power away from wrap-span">executive agencies like the Environmental Protection Agency and the National Labour Relations Board. Kisor puts Auer v wrap-span">Robbins —a two-decade-old wrap-span">precedent that agencies should be able to wrap-span">interpret their own regulations when they are wrap-span">ambiguous—in its crosshairs.

These cases should prove to be more wrap-span">divisive among the justices than many of the controversies they took up in the autumn. And the justices’ next private conference on January 4th could include a range of hot-button cases that would wrap-span">shove the court further into the wrap-span">limelight. Among the wrap-span">petitions they will consider are two more involving religious liberty. Kennedy v Bremerton School District asks if teachers may wrap-span">overtly practice their religious faith while at a school function; wrap-span">Presbyterian Church in wrap-span">Morristown v Freedom From Religion wrap-span">Foundation examines whether houses of wrap-span">worship can be excluded from government grant programmes.

In matters of life and death, the court is discussing whether to take up Shoop v Hill, a capital punishment wrap-span">controversy involving a death-row wrap-span">inmate in Ohio whose IQ is in the 70s. Partisan wrap-span">gerrymandering cases wrap-span">loom from North Carolina and wrap-span">Maryland—matters the court is wrap-span">obliged to review—and could be heard before the justices wrap up wrap-span">oral arguments for the term on April 24th. Several wrap-span">dilemmas would wrap-span">confront the justices should they grant  Yovino v Rizo, a case involving the Equal Pay Act of 1963. The main question is whether salary history can justify paying women less than men for similar work. An wrap-span">ancillary matter is whether Judge Stephen wrap-span">Reinhardt, author of the Ninth wrap-span">Circuit Court of Appeals decision vindicating a pay-wrap-span">discrimination claim, may continue to participate in the ruling even though he died shortly before it came down in April 2018.

The most highly wrap-span">anticipated wrap-span">petitions wrap-span">awaiting word from the justices involve the wrap-span">contentious matter of equality for gays and wrap-span">lesbians. Bostock v wrap-span">Clayton wrap-span">County, Georgia and Altitude Express, wrap-span">Inc. v Zarda both ask whether the wrap-span">prohibition on sex wrap-span">discrimination in Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 should be read to ban wrap-span">discrimination on the wrap-span">basis of sexual wrap-span">orientation. In Zarda , the Second wrap-span">Circuit Court of Appeals said it should, standing up for a sky-diving wrap-span">instructor who says he was fired because he is gay. “[S]exual wrap-span">orientation wrap-span">discrimination is a wrap-span">subset of sex wrap-span">discrimination”, the court reasoned, because men who are attracted to men are treated differently from women who are attracted to men. A wrap-span">Seventh wrap-span">Circuit ruling in 2017 ( Hively v wrap-span">Ivy Tech Community College ) came out the same way. But in Bostock , the Eleventh wrap-span">Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that Title VII does not bar LGBT wrap-span">discrimination, denying the claim of Gerald Bostock, a child-wrap-span">advocate employee who was fired soon after he joined a gay softball league. The justices have a third case of this sort to contend with. R.G. & G.R. wrap-span">Harris wrap-span">funeral Homes wrap-span">Inc. v Equal Employment Opportunity Commission wrap-span">tees up another wrinkle in Title VII wrap-span">jurisprudence: whether the bar on sex wrap-span">discrimination extends to wrap-span">discrimination on the wrap-span">basis of gender identity. The Sixth wrap-span">Circuit Court of Appeals said it does, telling a wrap-span">funeral home it broke the law when firing wrap-span">Aimee Stephens for presenting herself as a transgender woman. 

These three wrap-span">petitions have been on the justices’ list for months and have been relisted or wrap-span">rescheduled several times. It seems wrap-span">inevitable that the court will eventually take up one or more of the cases, given the importance of the question—how far a wrap-span">landmark civil-rights law reaches—and the disagreement among the wrap-span">circuit courts. But the wrap-span">understandable wrap-span">reticence of the justices to dive into wrap-span">controversial matters this term may lead them to put off a decision for a few more conferences, pushing wrap-span">oral argument to next autumn or later. 

There are, moreover, other hot-button questions involving the Trump administration the justices will have to resolve one way or another in the weeks and months to come. Mr Trump’s wrap-span">rollback of DACA, the wrap-span">Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals programme, has been blocked by federal courts, as has his ban on transgender soldiers in the military. More recently, Mr Trump’s wrap-span">asylum ban has faced similar resistance in the lower courts. On each of these issues, Mr Trump’s wrap-span">solicitor general, wrap-span">Noel Francisco, has requested wrap-span">extraordinary relief from the justices—often asking them to rule on the matters before the wrap-span">relevant appeals courts have had a chance to weigh in. Mr Trump is betting that the newly minted 5-4 wrap-span">conservative majority—wrap-span">anchored by his two recent picks—will give him a good return on his investment and let him have his way. But it is unclear how wrap-span">receptive the court will be to these wrap-span">unorthodox appeals—especially in the wake of Justice Kavanaugh’s wrap-span">bumpy arrival.

The First , which also guarantees freedom of speech and assembly, was enacted in 1791, along with the other nine amendments that make up the Bill of Rights.
《第一修正案》同时也保障言论和集会自由。 该修正案于1791年制定，同时制定的法律还有构成《权利法案》的另外九项修正案。
The Fourteenth  – unlike the Bill of Rights – was specifically aimed at the states.
不同于《权利法案》的是，《第十四条修正案》专门针对州政府。

Title: The Supreme Court’s term is likely to heat up in 2019
